title: A narrative on the neurobiological roots of attachment-system functioning
affiliations: University of Essex, Colchester, United Kingdom
background: Attachment theory is a comprehensive framework in social and developmental psychology describing how emotional bonds between infants and caregivers are formed and maintained, but lacks a cohesive biological narrative.
hypotheses: Organized attachment patterns systematically link the two primary purposes of the attachment behavioral system: tangible protection/support and the subjective feeling of safety/security.
Social allostasis-driven learning explains the dynamic adjustment of physiological balance in attachment pattern establishment and maintenance.
Epigenetic mechanisms contribute to attachment pattern formation and maintenance.
major_findings: A detailed neurobiological model of attachment behavior is proposed, linking sensory threat perception, physiological responses, proximity-seeking, reunion, and system deactivation.
Oxytocin, dopamine, noradrenaline, cortisol, and opioids are identified as key neurobiological players in attachment, with positive feedback loops maintaining proximity-seeking.
Epigenetic modifications, particularly DNA methylation, are suggested as mechanisms underlying individual differences in attachment patterns, influenced by maternal care and early adversity.
methods: integration of findings from animal and human studies
